description:
Actinomycetospora atypica is a species of bacteria that belongs to the phylum Actinobacteria. It is a Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, and non-motile actinomycete. The cells of A. atypica are typically coccoid or short rod-shaped, and they form branched, substrate-penetrating mycelium during growth.

This species was first isolated from soil samples collected in Japan. Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that A. atypica is closely related to other members of the genus Actinomycetospora, which are known to be aerobic, chemoorganotrophic, and capable of degrading various biopolymers.

The optimal growth conditions for A. atypica include a temperature range of 25-30Â°C and a neutral pH. This species is considered to be atypical within the genus Actinomycetospora due to its unique morphological and physiological characteristics, which differentiate it from the other recognized species in the genus.

Further studies on the ecology, metabolism, and potential applications of A. atypica may provide insights into the diversity and functional roles of this lesser-known group of actinomycete bacteria in natural environments.
